p: Smallmouth bass are a warm-water riverine species broadly distributed throughout North America. The Ozark-Ouachita Interior Highlands of Arkansas lie at the southern extent of smallmouth bass native range. The southern region of the United States is projected to warm 3–4°C by the year 2050 [ 12]. Along with the temperature change is an expected change in precipitation, including more extreme events leading to higher stochasticity and potentially an increase in flooding frequency and severity [ 25] even though average annual precipitation is projected to decrease slightly in parts of the southern region [ 12]. Precipitation patterns are likely to change seasonally and a decrease in precipitation is anticipated in the summer months [ 1], potentially leading to more severe and longer drought conditions [ 26]. At this southern range extent, smallmouth bass populations may be vulnerable to population declines due to climate change as summer temperatures will likely reach levels that will affect growth and survivorship [ 27]-[ 28], especially during summer drought conditions which are common in Arkansas streams and rivers [ 29]-[ 30]. Smallmouth bass are at risk of being outcompeted in some lotic habitats by largemouth bass and spotted bass, which both have a competitive advantage over smallmouth bass at higher temperatures [ 31].
